comments.commentBody: Israel has agreed to give up land for peace many times. Gaza is an example of what happens when Israel trusts an enemy whose stated goal is to obliterate Israel. Gaza has been used as a terrorist base to lob rockets at Israeli civilians on a daily basis. Hamas has built tunnels to be able to attack Israelis on their own territory. Yasser Arafat was offered 95% of what he asked for but still turned it down. There is no dealing with an enemy whose goal is to make Israel disappear. Let the so-called Palestinians, who are the grandchildren and great-grandchildren of those who left Israel because the other Arab nations told them they would be able to go back in a few days. That was 60 years ago. Palestinians are the only group in the world who are refugees for this long. Let them give some concessions. Start by recognizing that Israel is there permanently and they need to make peace.

Interesting piece of historical revisionism; and with a predictable agenda, to boot.

Yeltsin didn’t precipitate the disintegration of the USSR: he merely exploited an inevitability caused by a governance system that had failed for 73 years to materially improve the lives of the people it governed. Gorbachev personified that failed model; and, indeed, continued to defend it while out of office. Ronald Reagan’s concerted effort to bankrupt the USSR with an arms race they couldn’t afford certainly didn’t hurt.

The impression conveyed by this op-ed is that Gorbachev honorably acceded to provide a better future for his people and that of other peoples the Soviets had bound to them by force for decades. Nonsense. He surrendered in a war already lost, his empire broke and in crumbling ruins. If it remained marginally viable, he wouldn’t have surrendered.

That he saw to the responsible passing of nuclear weapons authority to Russia in a controlled manner was commendable but no more than one would have expected: if he hadn’t, the highly-scripted exchange between these two world leaders likely would have been quite different.

And now the agenda. Two presidents, world leaders both overflowing with competence and gravitas … compared to Donald J. Trump and Vladimir Putin. You could at least TRY not be so offensive while so laughably transparent.

Bush 41 managed his world well. Trump faces a fundamentally different world, and will use different means of managing it successfully.

I reread this piece searching for evidence about why Gorbachev resigned and could find none. I fail to see what is revisionist about what was printed. There are a mere 5 paragraphs in which the authors provide skeletal background for the text of the scripted verbatim conversation between these two leaders. I fail to see where it is revisionist, offensive or laughably transparent.

It will be 25 years since this conversation took place. The events leading to this conversation caused significant changes both then and for the future. Just as the 2016 US presidential election will significantly change the world in ways yet to unfold. Aside from the anniversary of this phone call, it is relevant because it contrasts the differences between the current leader of Russia and the soon to be leader of the US.

To point out those differences is not offensive. Unless of course you voted for Trump. The only thing potentially laughable here is Trump's transparency and the con he sold US voters. Unfortunately, those folks can't see that they've been duped! What you see is what you get. He lies despite video tape documentation, he is appointing more wealthy people to his cabinet than Carter's has liver pills. He encourages violence he bullies, he demeans women, minorities, the disabled. Worst of all he's legitimized extreme racism. This Alt Right stuff... you can put lipstick on a pig, but it's still a pig. Come to think of it, so is Donald Trump.
Thank you for an enlightened and unhinged comment. The vilification of Trump by the Times and its readers is amusing in its predictability but a bit frightening in its lack of veracity.

Wrong: Trump will definitely use different means, but NOT successfully. The fact that we won and they lost, and that this conversation was highly scripted, is not the point. DIPLOMACY is the point. Bush was a master at it, while Trump repeatedly tweets before he thinks. God help us all.

Our new kitty grabber in chief hasn't even been inaugurated yet and he's already a global threat.  Is that what his fan-base voted for?  Every dollar wasted on widening and "improving" a nuclear arsenal that is already equipped to destroy the planet many times over is a dollar deducted from the creation of jobs that was clearly the first thing on the minds of those who elected him.  The man is clearly showing his true colors here: he's an upraised middle finger confronting the world order and the best instincts of mankind.  (And btw: why the sudden need to respond to Putin's "provocation"? It's already been made obvious that The Donald's election is the gift that will keep on giving insofar as Prince Vlad the Hacker is concerned.)
The kiity grabber in chief no doubt was merely responding to Putin during a 3am station break of a replay of the Manchurian Candidate.
Both Trump and his fly-over territory supporters entertain a death wish generated by the old fogey's mortality and the Trump voters' utter lack of hope in the improvement of their lot.

stu - Indeed; DJT and Vlad aren't merely flirting with the Arms Control Race harlot - they've been caught red-handed (so to speak) en flagrante with her in a lurid porno which should be consigned to XXX-dom.

Nonsense.

Putin said some belligerent things about increasing nuclear arms in a speech to his generals.

Trump responded to that, if Putin wants an arms race we'll win it.

Putin came back in his year end press conference replying, no no, he did not mean that, he'd actually reduce spending.

Problem solved.

All that is left is hysteria. Hate Trump. Fear Trump. He'll kill us all.

Nonsense.

Do you just figure the existing bureaucracy will not change policy with every tweet? That Trump's posturing will scare our enemies even though we citizens are sure he doesn't mean half of what he says? What is the upside of having this man tweet his off the cuff opinions?
Keep your head deep in the sand, and maybe you'll survive the blast.

This is the following syndrome: Trump will be so terrible that he will cleanse the body politic and in 2020 there will be a perfect Democrat who will bring purity. A combination of nihilism and wishfulness. If we're all here in four years, it's not going to happen. It didn't happen with Nixon. It didn't happen with Bush.

Tom:

The conversation obviously was highly-scripted, on BOTH sides. And Gorbachev's English was rudimentary while Bush's Russian was non-existent. They obviously spoke their own languages and translators conveyed the words. Bush and Gorbachev appeared jointly at symposia for years after both were out of office, and Gorby was an active international traveler in retirement, so they probably maintained a passable relationship, to the extent that men who don't speak the other's tongue can.
Not familiar with shawty. but back in the day "short" referred to a car.  "Grab your short and let's head down to the Workshop to catch Miles."
Thanks, Tom! Today I learned something new.

The Israeli's have called the PLO bluff four times over the last thirty years and each time the PLO walked away. Do not attempt to rewrite history. Settlements aside, the PLO does not recognize Israel's right to exist. Hezbollah sends rockets from Gaza and Iran threatens to wipe them from the face of the earth.

What problem have the Muslim nations of the Middle East solved? They use the "PLO problem" as a distraction form their own failed economies. Everyone, including some commenters here, want Israel to make another grand gesture to the Palestinians. The PLO has rejected every one so far. Palestinians could have had a fully functioning state by now had the stayed at the negotiating table. Stop falling for this nonsense put forth by countries who simply want to weaken Israel and make the U.S. look like fools. President Obama is destroying what little he has left of his legacy by getting in political bed with monsters who strap bombs on children. Unfortunately, this resolution will to be reversed by the Security Council and I suggest the U.N. find another home in Europe. I'm sure new Zealand, Malaysia, Egypt and other countries will step up and fund the deficits for this cabal of horrors.

Instead of seeking serious dialogue with his friend Putin on nuclear restraint, what Trump is rather getting ecstatic about is that how fast he reaches the nuclear sight and lays hands on the  nuclear button. Rest would be a play for him however dangerous that might be.
Hopefully, professor, you are being sarcastic. If not then I feel sorry for your students.

@Richard:  President Obama's "failures" had everything to do with not wanting to send American troops into every corner of the world that had turned into a hell-hole since the last Republican president decided to attack the wrong country.  I've disagreed with some of his individual decisions but you're dreaming if you really believe that he or The Donald or any other U.S. chief executive has the power or the authority to prevent Sunnis and Shiites and Israelis from killing one another or Russia from invading Crimea (not that Mr. Trump has anything much to say about the latter event in any case). Much of the world is in turmoil right now but the U.S. (even including New Jersey) remains a pretty safe place in which to live.  For that you can thank our incumbent President and his sensible homeland security policies.  If his successor means to "shake things up" it's far more likely that the end result will be less safety and security for the U.S. and no reduction at all in the upheaval being experienced outside of our borders. (And, btw, who is it again who's been threatening to curtail payment on Europe's defense?)
...That moment when you realize EHARMONY and HAM ON RYE are anagrams of each other.

I can understand why you're putting those questions out there.  It's hard to believe that anyone elected to the highest office in the land can be as big an idiot as our new kitty grabber in chief "pretends" to be.  Surely there's a strategy involved and we citizens of normal intelligence (let alone the college-educated "elites") just don't have the perception to suss it out.

I'm not on the same political side as George Bush Senior, but he and Gorbachev were both good men. I wish the same could be said of Putin and trump; whatever accommodation these kindred spirits reach only bodes ill for the future

It's worth speculating how different subsequent history might have turned out if the west had not almost casually allowed NATO to expand to Russia's border, despite assurances to the contrary. I doubt if the United States would take kindly to a Russian military presence in this hemisphere, as the Cuba Missile Crisis proved. NATO expansion was one of two factors that almost guaranteed the rise to power of Putin or someone like him. The other factor was Russia's cold-turkey embrace of raw capitalism, largely on the advice of Chicago-school economists who descended on Russia en masse, seeing it as a lab for their ideology. Ordinary Russians went through an extended period of privation which soured them on democracy and steered them towards electing an autocrat. The rest is history.

Putin is the same character as a capitalist oligarch/autocrat that he was as communist KGB chief. He pines for the old Soviet sphere of influence and wants to "make Russia great again". He wants NATO gone. So naturally he makes nice to NATO-skeptic trump.

Whether its expansion was a good idea or not, it's now a necessary reality for helping defend Russia's neighbors. You can't blame them for being nervous. We live in dangerous times.

The "NATO expansion forced poor Russia to defend itself" narrative is tiring.

No NATO forces had been rebased closer to Russia after 1991, on the contrary, US tank brigades from Germany had been shipped back to the US.

If Russia is "so afraid" of e.g. Poland being a NATO member, WITHOUT NATO forces stationed in Poland, then I am sure Russia can appreciate Polish concerns about Russian tanks hanging VERY close.

As it is, Russia saysit is afraid of Poland. Do you believe this?

I agree with mancuroc's statement re the West "casually" allowing expansion of NATO to Russia's border having played a significant role in today's increasingly tense and contentious situation. Our naivete about projecting presumably legitimate values, of promoting democracy in the unstable, rapidly changing political circumstances in the former USSR's sphere of influence, was deeply ahistorical. A complex set of social, political and economic forces were unleashed with the unraveling of the USSR and Gorbachev's resignation. However, I think that what was under-appreciated in the West was Russia's underlying need to maintain a  buffer zone securing it from any future German invasion. The US legitimately takes its share of credit for its heroic role in WW II, but Putin has tapped into Russia's awareness that it lost 10,000,000 in military deaths and another 16,000,000 in civilian deaths during the war. Compare that to US losses of 407,000 and 12,000, respectively, a completely different order of magnitude, and you get a sense of how our values of promoting democracy might be seen as an existential threat.

Poland certainly has to worry about Putin's intentions. Latvia, Lithuania, Estonia and others that were once behind the Iron Curtain are in similar position. But imagine US reaction if Mexico and Canada were to join alliance with Russia and its "partners" that specifies (as per Article 5 of NATO treaty) that “an armed attack against one or more of them… shall be considered an attack against them all” and that following such an attack, each Ally would take “such action as it deems necessary, including the use of armed force” in response.

Just saying that fear and security within historical context are under-appreciated.

It's been awhile since I've heard a pretty good Catholic mass homily -- it's been a long time since I've attended a mass that wasn't a wedding, a funeral or a baptism.

But, then, I have nobody to blame but myself: I didn't need to read this op-ed, did I?
No, but the honesty, as always, is refreshing.
That should read: "Bernie Sanders wouldn't survive the early Southern primaries".
Security Council can't do a thing about Syria because RUSSIA would veto it.

Ron,
The people of Israel want peace.When the Palestinians accept Israel's right to exist as a Jewish State ,settlements, land, reparations for lost property can be negotiated.Of course land stolen from Jews in Arab countries need to be also compensated.
You are lucky that you were born in this country and parents survived.I have a different point of view based on being a survivor with most of my family gassed in concentration camps.
With antisemitism rising all over the world I want a Jewish State and don't have the hutzpah to tell Israel how to save that sliver of land where a jew can be safe.

Gemli, you potter about in such a simple, imaginary world of your own construction, one that has never existed in all our time on this Earth since BEFORE we swung down from the trees and started making such nuisances of ourselves. On the evidence, what is rational and simple hasn't had the best run, has it?

While Wehner may not fit the template, there is a REASON why religion is the opiate of the masses: they need it, whether they call themselves Republicans OR Democrats. And, while I've personally known many priests, I don't believe a single one of them was a Republican.

Historians tell us Jesus was a very nice Jewish boy who was born in the spring.

Beyond that, the audit trail is pret-t-t-t-y weak, and frankly, embarrassingly suspicious.

We know humans are absolute suckers for storytelling and we know that the sweet baby Jesus son of 'God' Resurrection story is an absolute whopper-doozy of the Highest order.

Even today, in the modern age, with cameras, recordings and incontrovertible evidence of the opposite, 52% of Republicans think Donald Trump won the popular vote just last month, so of course it's certainly no surprise that the old Jesus fable still holds some of that atavistic suspension of disbelief magic for lots of folks who were scared to death and smashed in the head with a theology book as youngsters and never made a full recovery.

Every one loves and admires Jesus...even a devout atheist like me.

But the Mahatma Gandhi definition of Christianity has never been disproved and until it is, Christianity shall remain a phantom, dwarf planet religion in need of a serious makeover:

“I like your Christ, I do not like your Christians. Your Christians are so unlike your Christ.”
― Mahatma Gandhi

Or as old Friedrich Nietzsche told us, "the last Christian died on the cross".

Merry Hoaxmas to all !
Hoaxes don't last this long?  Huh.  There are all sorts of different religions, all over the world, all based on myths of one sort or another.  So yes, hoaxes DO last that long.

@Yggdrasil: So objective truth exists "since" there is an objective truth-giver? Hence, what *makes* those objectively true things true is that the truth-giver gives them to us? What about the fact, if it is a fact, that the truth-giver gives them to us? Is that true only because the truth-giver gives it to us?

It would seem that if, according to the theist, "objective" truth depends on God, then all the theist's "truths," such as 2 + 2 = 4, are only in the head of the theist or God. It is, however, open to the atheist to think that the way the world is doesn't care what we believe.

Did you know that when you exclude the votes from new York City and Los Angeles trump won the popular vote? Which is exactly why the electoral college was instated.

But regardless. As we all know,it is impossible to derive any meaning from something that isn't 100% accurate. After all, if it's not true you may have to contemplate something, thereby passing age old questions through contemporary understanding and discovering new meaning. What's the point of a holy book if the big cheese doesn't just hand out the answers? What kind of horrible parent doesn't instantly and immediately give their child whatever the brat screams for?

Oops; hit "submit" in error.  Anyway, it's become more and more obvious over the course of these last 18 months or so that there really IS nothing behind The Donald's tough talk, offensive attitudes and simple-minded policy pronouncements.  He's just a malevolent version of that Chauncey Gardner character in "Being There": a fool to whom other people, including members of the intelligentsia, are attributing cunning motives and artful indirection because they simply can't believe that anyone who's made so much money (even with the assistance of his successful dad who left him the business, his expensive accountants and tax attorneys and the creditors and employees who he never bothers to thank) could possibly be such a complete ignoramus.  Surprise, America!  That statement about his not needing intelligence briefings because he's already so smart pretty much tells you all you need to know.

Trump is more strident and more obnoxious than Hillary. If he is not more sneaky, it is because he does not bother to sneak. He is open and does so many unexpected and contradictory things that whatever he is up to remains obscured.

If she had been running against Romney, this explanation might make sense. But she was running against Trump. She did much better than Jeb!, Marco, or Ted, but not quite well enough. Her problem was not so much her bad points as what Donald was able to make of them.

Maybe the electoral trend that put Trump within striking distance of victory were clear for months, but they were not clear to most political prognosticators.  So to whom were they clear, except hindsight?

The American people are at the mercy of the fragile ego of Donald Trump. It really doesn't matter what his motive is: whether his tough talk is simply an "an opening bid" , or a pointed reminder to Russia that the guard has changed in Washington.

But the fact that he feels compelled to respond instantly to an address from Russia or any other hotspot, is alarming. He has a knee-jerk need to jump into the fray long before he and his aides have considered all their options.

Let's face it: Trump is a hothead. NSA advisor Michael Flynn is a hothead. Bannon is a hothead, although he has more patience the Donald.

Elsewhere in reporting on this issues, it was said that "Trump flicked away the efforts of aides to get him to calm down."

If Donald Trump refuses to listen to the very people with the power to challenge Trump's lousy self-control, we're in far worse trouble than even I thought a month ago.

Which brings this American back to her first comment when Mr. Trump announced that he was running for President.  It is not right for the Media to poke fun at a person suffering from an emotional disorder and some kind soul should take him care of him.  This did not happen and now we are discussing the threat of nuclear warfare on the eve of Christmas.  I fear I am an awful fool.

Hi Christine,
Here we are. The day before Christmas, doomed with ah, we'll really, I can't even think of a descriptive word, a person, who you were so right about.
I cannot believe I wrote a sentence to you several weeks ago that maybe things would be "ok" with him. We can clearly see the picture now. Yes, he sorrounds himself with those you mention. We see his tweets like a silly dangerous child. We read about and acknowledge those who he has chosen to lead his cabinet and his days in our country's Oval Office, which we citizens turn over to him.

We are in disbelief, disgust, heart ache - not necessarily even for us, but in my case, for my kids, my grandchildren, and everybody else's families, too!
Well, let us, in the midst of it, do something special to celebrate the holiday weekend and New Year, something very unDonald Trump, which is blatant - love our neighbor, whoever it is and rejoice we think how we do, and be grateful we find like minded people who still fight for right - right here in The NY Times comment section! :) That goes for you, Christine. A special day to ya'. Carry on, friend!

@Miss Ley: is your fear because nobody listened to you, or did you by chance vote for him because the media continued to be against him?  My fear is that an awful lot of people are waking up to the fact that maybe voting for him was not such a great idea and now it's too late.

Don't be so sure, Mark. Trump's an erratic, pathological liar and Putin is a nogoodnik. As my wife said, "Don't turn your back on Vladimir."

Trump obviously hasn't given nuclear proliferation or an arms race much thought, besides what takes to do a Tweet, so who knows what craziness he'll come up with.

The main issue never faced by the intelligentsia in the U.S. has come back finally to haunt us with a vengeance.  If the contradictions related here were faced perhaps we would not be in this boat.  China and other Asian nations are meritocracies where testing determines in large measure Government positions and entrance to Universities making well paying jobs more likely.   The U.S. has today minimal opportunities for non college graduate.   China has taken first our low wage jobs and now our Engineering Jobs along with India as it does not pay to manufacture here.   They will soon not ship much back here as that there will not be enough productive workers to pay for the foreign goods.  Tariffs and VATs worldwide protect more savvy economies like Germany protect their labor force via underselling by wage slave labor.   Liberals have never faced directly the costs as well as benefits of free trade.   Alexander Hamilton had a protectionist solution which worked for a long time as it kept jobs and Engineering here based on the then world dominant education system.   After world war II protectionism was unnecessary and dropped.   We have engaged in a race to the bottom wagewise and the economy has showed this.  We need an intelligent industrial and trade policy.  I hope this can work but the voice of academic economists say it won't.  Time will tell.  One cannot blame Trump for trying.

Actually, although economics itself is a subject worthy of study, macroeconomics has not performed well in the last few years.

The reason is that practitioners want to talk about important things, and received accolades from the power structure. Krugman for example was perhaps angling for a position in a Clinton administration. So they bowdlerize their subject to make it more appealing to one of the flavors of politicians.

Krugman excoriates those economists with a conservative bent and provides his own version of Keynesianism.

Make no mistake. Keynes was an important economist and his ideas have merit. But in the hands of Krugman those ideas are subordinated to politics.

When it comes to trade policy, yes, free trade has benefited the wealthy, but not so much the white patriarchs, vilified by the left, who were once the backbone of the American middle class.

Krugman is clueless about this demonization of forgotten Americans. They have spoken by voting for Trump.

The antidote would be for liberalism to start actually supporting the poor, whose lives it claims to be concerned about.

A little less sanctimony and a little more honesty.

At least Trump says up front that he will s***w the little guy.

Liberals proclaim that they want to help the poor, then provide Obamacare which has not stopped the exponential rise in health care costs.

Both parties lie, but the Democratic lies are the more preposterous.
Nice set of unsupported assertions by who?  Really, Who are you and why should a reader believe you?

No Blaise, you need to look at your own Being, which, prior to your transformation, is the Source of your constant ragging of Krugman, a Nobel Prize recipient in economics. You seem unable to get that all your rationalizations only expose what you fail to see in yourself. Seek help as you've certainty demonstrated you need it.
Does Trump really have to be president? Can't something be done? At least Pence is sane and normal? Trump should be declared unfit for the job  which he definitely is.
Pence only looks normal next to Trump.

So now Christians are unfit to be president? If all the left believes that then you will not win the presidency for a heck of a long time. Radical members of the left say just as asinine stuff as the far right.

Am I the only one hoping against hope that there are some kind of negotiations going on between the GOP and Democratic elders in DC to neutralize the cruel orangutang? Whether by impeachment or some other maneuver, surely it's crystal clear by now that DT cannot be allowed to serve as our president. Everybody's survival is on the line!
